Get and set sys_tmp_dir (#2445)

When compacting the Realm on external storage for Android, SharedGroup
always uses the default sys_tmp_dir which is invalid for Android. Thus
we need an API for setting the default sys_tmp_dir for bindings.
The getters is also required since ObjectStore may use it to create
pipe/fifo.

To solve java issue https://github.com/realm/realm-java/issues/4140

Merge pull request #2303 from realm/tg/query-reimport

Fix a crash when reimporting a Query into the same SharedGroup as it was exported from

Fix a crash when reimporting a Query into the same SharedGroup as it was exported from

`m_table` needs to not be set on the handover Query in order for the column
references to be updated properly when re-importing it into the same
SharedGroup. This could theoretically cause problems when exporting and
importing into a different SharedGroup, but it's very unlikely (it'd require
that the source SharedGroup be destroyed and then the target one happen to
allocate the equivalent Table at the same memory address).

The removed assertion was not actually asserting anything sensible (`m_table`
was previously the same table as it was getting the column index from, so it
wasn't an interesting assert, and now is null so the assert would just crash).

Merge pull request #2236 from realm/jed/depreate-some-constructors

Deprecate Array type parameters in Column<T> and BpTree<T> constructors

Use macro to signal deprecated function

MSVC does not support C++14 attributes

Deprecate Array type parameters in Column<T> and BpTree<T> constructors

Exposing Array type through the public interface is exposing the
implementation. We might not use Array as the fundamental BpTree
building block forever.

If you use the deprecated function, you can instead do like this:

    ref_type ref = BpTree<int>::create_leaf(Array::type_Normal, 0, 0, alloc);
    _impl::DeepArrayRefDestroyGuard dg_2(ref, alloc);
    auto bp_tree = std::make_unique<BpTree<int>>(alloc, ref); // Throws
    bp_tree->set_parent(...);
    bp_tree->root().update_parent(); // Throws
    dg_2.release(); // Ownership transferred

Merge pull request #2181 from realm/dp/afl_set_unique

Added SET_UNIQUE instruction to AFL

Updating unit test StringIndex_Fuzzy

This is an updated version of the unit test that was added in dc566f5b3.
The error that this test exposed was due to the way the test was
implemented. It inserted a value into the column which was the result of
a get from the same column. As we use StringData to hold the data to be
inserted, we have a direct pointer to where the string data is stored. In
this case we use long strings which means that many strings are stored in
the same blob. If the value to be replaced is stored in the same blob as
the new value and the old value comes first, then the new value will move
in memory before the copy is done because we need to adjust for the new
size. So the pointer we get passed in becomes stale and we get the wrong
value copied in (which will have no index).

The new test case is modified in the way that we first copy the content out
in some temporary strings before inserting them again.

Merge branch 'master' into jed/apply-clang-format

Specify the `CC` environment variable rather than `CXX` when building
for Apple platforms.

`CC` is used as the value for the C++, Objective-C and Objective-C++
compilers if specified, while `CXX` is only used for C++. This was
resulting in C, Objecive-C and Objective-C++ code building with  the
wrong SDK when building using `build-cocoa` and the subcommands that it
delegates to.

Change indentation implementation in dump functions

Instead of having an integer level passed to the dump functions, we will
have an indentation string. 2 spaces are added when passing the string to
next level.

This makes the output statements more simple.
stdint.h -> cstdint
time.h -> ctime
assert.h -> cassert
stdio.h -> cstdio
errno.h -> cerrno
math.h -> cmath
float.h -> cfloat
stdlib.h -> cstdlib
stdio.h -> cstdio
stdarg.h -> cstdarg
stddef.h -> cstddef
signal.h -> csignal
string.h -> cstring
wchar.h -> cwchar

Add space after template keyword

This is mandatory in current clang-format version.
A new option to remove it again will come in V4.0.

Remove definition of TableView destructor

Having the destructor defined, prevents the generation of at least the
move constructor and move assignment operator. This is not a problem
in released code, as the need for those functions are most probably
optimized out. In debug mode, however, we have a fundamentally different
behavior, where the copy constructors are used where we would expect move
constructor. Also the comments hints that the class is moveable.

Use -fsigned-char to build (#2033)

This is found when compiling realm-java with cmake. The different
default sets on different targets cause linking failed with lto enabled.

The problem is, cmake toolchain shipped with google sdk has
 -fsigned-char by default.
See https://github.com/taka-no-me/android-cmake/blob/master/android.toolchain.cmake#L1237

But the default gcc has different signed/unsigned for different
targets, eg.: arm64 by default is unsigned-char.

Rework Query initialization to support adding columns

This changes all query nodes to use the following pattern:

  1. On initial creation, store the passed-in column index.
  2. When the node is added to a Query, bind to that Query's table immediately
     rather than waiting until the Query is run, and never refer to the column
     index again after this.
  3. When cloning for handover, construct the new nodes using the column
     indexes from the actual columns rather than the originally passed-in values.

The third part requires making it so that columns which are part of tables keep
track of their logical index within the table. Table and Link columns did this
already (although Link columns did not properly update it after new columns
were added), so that functionality was just moved to ColumnBase.

Use shared_ptr for Descriptor

To ensure the thread safety of destructors.

Root descriptor is created by table which also keeps a shared ref
on it. Sub descriptor is created by root descriptor which also keeps
a shared ref on it. This means for most cases, the descriptors live
as long as the root table. Don't hold a shared ref on it to avoid
circular refs.

Workaround for mkfifo bug on BB devices (#1985)

Fix for https://github.com/realm/realm-java/issues/3178

BB 10's mkfifo() has a bug. When the fifo file exists, from the
document, errno EEXIST should be set. But instead, it fails with
error ENOSYS which is translated to exception message "Function
not implemented".

To solve this, we use stat to check if the path exists and it is
a fifo.

Have `LinkListColumn::get_ptr` do a better job of reusing tombstone
entries in its cached accessor list.

`LinkListColumn` stores a vector of accessors sorted by their row index.
When an accessor is destroyed, its entry in the vector becomes a
tombstone, represented by an expired `m_list` `weak_ptr`.
`LinkListColumn::get_ptr` can reuse these tombstone entries rather than
inserting new entries into `m_list_accessors` when doing so would
preserve the correct order. This is the case when one of the entries
adjacent to where the new entry would be inserted is a
tombstone. Reusing the entry avoids repeatedly growing the accessor
vector in many common scenarios that involve short-lived link list
accessors, improving performance.

Merge pull request #1880 from realm/jed/improve-line-coverage

Introduce REALM_NEVER and REALM_ALWAYS macros

Introduce REALM_NEVER and REALM_ALWAYS macros

These macros are introduced in order to be able to indicate that some
conditions are supposed to be either always or never true during unit
testing. When measuring the test coverage, the macros will defined as
'false' and 'true' resp. This will give the compiler the possibility
to optimize out the condition and in this way give a more useful coverage
score.

Merge pull request #1820 from realm/tg/fsync-writelog

Remove unnecessary fsync()s of commit log files

Remove unnecessary fsync()s of commit log files

The writelogs do not need to survive power loss (or even ever actually hit disk
at all), so there's no need to call `File::sync()` on them. These were
incorrectly added by the combination of
0d2fd43a08734fecbaa2ceb30c7ecdd6a5bd3869 and
185de19a140c4c9cd2f6dcb46679e16db853df05: the first made all calls to
`File::resize()` call `fsync()` even though only resizes of the Realm file
itself need it, and the second fixed this by pulling the call to `fsync()` out
of `resize()`, but did so even in the places where the sync was not required.

There is a remaining call to `msync()` on the log files before flipping the
active file bit in the header which has a much smaller impact on performance.

This cuts the time to open a SharedGroup on an iPad Air from 100ms to 30ms (and
makes it not bound on disk write speed) and makes commits a bit faster (~10%
for very small ones).

in case of stale mmap: remove assert but make sure we use a new mapping

Fix handing over an out-of-date TableView representing backlinks to a
deleted row.

Handed-over `TableView`s were using a magic version number of -1 to represent
that the view is out of sync. `TableView::outside_version` was using
this same magic version number to indicate that the view depends on a
deleted link list or row. This could lead to handing-over an out of sync
`TableView` creating a `TableView` that always believed itself to be in
sync, and thus could never be brought back in sync.

To address this we change `TableView::m_last_seen_version` to be
`Optional`, with the empty optional representing the fact that no
version has been seen yet.

Merge pull request #1710 from realm/mar/tableview-backlinks-row-accessor

Fix TableViews based on backlinks to work correctly when their row is moved or removed

Fix incorrect comparison semantics when comparing a LinkList column with
a Row using a query expression.

The old query fallback path that attempts to take advantage of
`Query::links_to`'s performance was being selected in cases where it has
different semantics than we need. In particular, the sequence of
`Query::Not` / `Query::links_to` on a link list column only matches rows
where none of the links is equal to the row we're looking
for. Comparisons against values from link lists are expected to match if
any of the values fulfills the criteria.

This was noticed due to "failing" tests when run with
`REALM_OLDQUERY_FALLBACK` disabled. The failing results were in fact the
correct results, with the test having the wrong expectations.

Fix `TableView`s based on backlinks to work correctly when their row is moved or removed.

Have `TableView` hold a row accessor so that it always tracks the same
row's backlinks.

Have `TableView` and `Query` expose whether their rows are guaranteed to
be in table order.

The change calculation logic in Cocoa's fine-grained notifications has
an optimization for rows guaranteed to be in table order, but knowing
when this optimization can be activated requires tracking the source of
each `TableView`. This is unnecessary given that a `TableView` itself
already knows its source and therefore knows whether its rows are
guaranteed to be in table order.

Fix a crash when result_ndx is null in  Table::minimum_timestamp() and Table::maximum_timestamp()

The out parameter to get the index of the minimum/maximum row is optional for
all of the other minmax functions.

Don't throw an exception from make_dir() when the directory already exists

And instead return a bool for that.

Checking if the directory already exists before trying to create it runs into
TOCTOU issues, so the directory already existing can't reasonably be considered
an error case. Swallowing the exception when the calling code doesn't care
about it makes debugging more difficult, and when it does need to do something
different, using the exception for control flow would be ugly.

Handing over an in-sync `TableView` based on a `Query` that is restricted to a
`TableView` should result in a `TableView` that is also in-sync.

The order of operations performed within `TableViewBase`'s handover
constructor was resulting in the source `TableView` falling out of sync
before it could be queried to populate the `was_in_sync` flag of the
handover patch. This happened due to `is_in_sync()` depending on the
source `TableView` being intact, while the `Query` handover constructor
had handed over any restricting `TableView` and invalidated them in the
process.

We fix this by populating the `was_in_sync` flag before handing over the
`Query`.

Fix double deletion of a `TableView` due to a bug in `Query`'s move
constructor and move assignment operators.

`Query`'s move constructor and move assignment operators were
defaulted, resulting in both the moved and the target objects thinking
they owned the source table view if the moved object originally owned it.

Fix this by using a `unique_ptr` to represent ownership of the source
table view, removing the ability to unintentionally give ownership to
multiple objects.

Merge pull request #1598 from realm/mar/query-backlinks

Add support for querying over backlinks

Have `Table`'s reference counting use atomic operations.

In #826, it was made safe to destroy a `Row` accessor from any thread as
it's difficult to prevent users of the Cocoa binding from doing this
unintentionally. An oversight in this change is that `Row` holds a
reference to the `Table` it belongs to, but `Table`s reference counting
is not threadsafe. This means there is the potential for adjustments to
the reference count to be missed due to concurrent adjustments on
another thread. We address this by switching to atomic operations for
manipulating the reference count.

Note that this change does not make it safe for the final reference to
a `Table` to be dropped from an arbitrary thread. `Table`s destructor
interacts with other objects, so correct synchronization is necessary to
ensure that no data races occur during the destructor's execution.

A redo of the commit bcf141b
which changed some integer types in input_stream.hpp.

The current code makes all relevant types version_type.

Added -Wshorten-64-to-32 flag to project.mk

This flag will trigger warnings on 32 bit builds.
The resolution of those warnings will take place in the coming commits.

The warnings typically represent assignment between incompatible integer types.

int_type_1 x = int_type_2 y;

On a 32-bit build, the warning is triggered if int_type_1 is 32-bit and int_type_2 is 64-bit.
The warning is a sign that the integer types are used incorrectly. Even on a 64-bit build where the two types
would typically both be 64-bit, the code is still suffering from logically incomatible assignments.
Fixing the 32-bit warnings hence leads to nicer code even on 64-bit builds.

Unit testing: New option for logging to files (one per test thread) (`UNITTEST_LOG_TO_FILES=1`).
Unit testing: New option for aborting of first check failure, or unexpected exception throwin in test (`UNITTEST_ABORT_ON_FAILURE=1`).
Unit testing: New logging features available in tests (util::Logger).

Ensure that all query node `apply_handover_patch` methods call through
to their superclass.

Failing to call through to the superclass results in subsequent ANDed
nodes being skipped when applying patches. This was hitting an assertion
failure in `Query::apply_patch` that verified that all query node
patches were applied, and would have resulted in incorrect query results
for some handed-over queries if assertions were disabled.

Fail when we encounter an outdated configuration rather than attempting
to automatically reconfigure.

Automatically reconfiguring will silently clobber the user's existing
configuration. Failing allows them to re-run `sh build.sh config` with
their desired paramaters.

Issue replication instruction from Table::clear() in the right order.
Much more unit testing.
condvar refinement and explanatory comments
Remove some duplication that is unnecessary now that we construct the deployment target flag in the same way for simulator and device builds.
Ignore new files and directories produced by build-osx.

Provide the `REALM_COCOA_PLATFORMS` environment variable to allow
restricting which platforms are built via `sh build.sh build-cocoa`.

This allows quicker iteration on testing core changes in the Cocoa
binding as you can now easily rebuild, for example, only the OS X
version of core. This previously required either manually copying around
the built libraries or suffering through a rebuild of all Cocoa
platforms.
Have build-osx, and thus build-cocoa, build using the same SDK-based mechanism as the other Apple platforms.

Use SDK identifiers rather than walking the file system to discover
available SDKs.

The presence of SDKs is confirmed using `xcodebuild -version -sdk foo`,
and the compiler is now invoked using `xcrun -sdk foo c++`.

This changes the file names of the iOS, tvOS and watchOS libraries built
by `build-cocoa` as they now include the SDK identifier rather than a
title-case variant of the platform name.

Throw exceptions on decryption failure rather than terminate()
Only test opening unencrypted files with a key if encryption is enabled

Throw exceptions on decryption failure rather than terminate()

This will still normally result in terminate() being called due to throwing out
of a noexcept function, but it makes it so that the detection of invalid
encryption keys on open is not reliant on the first page failing to decrypt and
simplifies things.

The actual bug fixed by this is that when the first four bytes of the file were
zero the first page would be treated as uninitialized rather than encrypted
with a different key, and then reading the footer would call terminate() if the
IV for that file position was not also zero.

Move `Expression` to unique ownership and make it cloneable.

This prevents a single `Expression` from being shared between multiple
`Query` objects, paving the way for allowing handover within the
expression hierarchy.

Introduce `ConstantStringValue`, a subclass of `Value<StringData>` that
owns the string data that it holds.

This encapsulates the need to copy and delete the string within the
value class, rather than having it be split between `create` and
`Compare`. This is necessary in order to allow `Compare` to be cloneable
in the future.
Updated set_table() to include the Table* parameter, to work with: https://github.com/realm/realm-core/pull/1332

Implement support for subqueries.

This provides subqueries using the syntax from #905. The evaluation of
subqueries operates by explicitly evaluating the subquery for each
linked row and counting the number of linked rows that matched. In the
future we can short-circuit evaluation when the target match count is
exceeded for subqueries of the form:

    table1->column<LinkList>(col_link2, table2->column<Int>(0) == 1).count() > 0

Remove use of auto when confusing

Use universal references in range-based for loops

The reason to prefer universal references in range-based for loops is
that dereferencing itertors in C++11 doesn't necessarily yield an
lvalue. Thus, using `auto&` or `const auto&` would not be able to
capture that.

The rest of this PR follows the same style, and only uses const
references when it is explicitly declared as such.

Alternatively, it would be possible to have

    template <typename T> T const& as_const(T const& v) { return v; }

which would then give us the ability to use

    for (auto&& x : f) { ... } // non-necessarily const
    for (auto&& x : as_const(f)) { ... } // always const

and be even more explicit.

Avoid linear scans when creating and updating link list accessors.

`LinkListColumn` now keeps its `m_list_accessors` vector sorted by row
index. This allows us to use binary searches instead of linear scans to
locate the accessor for a given row. The tradeoff is that methods which
update existing accessors need to perform more work to maintain that
sorted order. In practice, the benefit from avoiding the linear searches
appears to more than compensate for maintaining the ordering.

In addition to storing `m_list_accessors` in sorted order, it may now
contain entries with null `m_list` members. These members are used as
tombstones to represent deleted items, whose removal from the vector is
now deferred until the next mutation. This is done to amortize the O(n)
cost of `std::vector::erase` that would otherwise be incurred each time
an accessor is removed.

Don't have make limit the number of jobs based on load average on OS X.

This makes build-cocoa around 25% faster on my MacBook Pro, decreasing
the time taken from ~23 minutes down to ~17 minutes.

The way that OS X computes load average is somewhat different than
Linux. Building with a limit of only 4 jobs can easily send the load
average up around 20. This results in substantially less parallelism
than expected. Rather than trying to determine a reasonable load average
for make to limit itself to on OS X, I've opted to just disable limiting based
on load average.

Fix `Optional`s buggy copy and move assignment operators.

Both assignment operators failed to set `m_engaged` when assigning an
engaged optional to an unengaged optional. The lack of test coverage for
these operators caused this issue to be missed.

Additionally, `Optional`s value assignment operator was insufficiently
constrained resulting in compile errors when attempting to use the copy
assignment operator due to ambiguity between the copy assignment and
value assignment operators. To address this, the value assignment
operator is now constrained to argument types as per
[optional.object.assign.11][1]

[1]: http://www.open-std.org/jtc1/sc22/wg21/docs/papers/2014/n3848.html#optional.object.assign

Use `std::string` rather than introducing `OwnedStringData`.

`StringNodeBase` now stores `m_value` as an `Optional<std::string>`. To make this ergonomic,
`StringData` gains a converting constructor from `util::Optional<std::string>` to propagate
nullability from the `Optional`.

`StringNode` now stores `m_ucase` and `m_lcase` as `std::string`s. To avoid unnecesary heap
allocations during their initialization, the signature of `case_cmp` is updated to return an
`Optional<std::string>`. This allows the small string optimization to store data on the stack
before we move it into `StringNode`s members. The disengaged state of the `Optional` is used
to communicate a failure to convert the input to the desired case. Since a number of callers
of `case_map` don't deal with errors from the function, an overload is added with a flag to
suppress errors. In this case the return value in the error case is simply an empty string.
Version bump 0.93.0 -> 0.94.0
Add a note to the release notes about the nesting level limitation being lifted.

Add an overload of `Query::and_query` that takes an rvalue.

This avoids copying the node hierarchy in the extremely common case that we're
combining the query with a temporary.

In the future it may be beneficial for `Query::operator&&` and `Query::operator||`
to be overloaded for rvalues as well. I'm not adding those overloads at present as
the methods are not used by the Cocoa or Android bindings, so it doesn't seem worth
the complexity that the additional overloads per method would add.

Move the query node hierarchy to unique ownership.

The `QueryGroup` owns the root node of its hierarchy, and each node
below it owns its direct children. Copying the `Query` copies its
`QueryGroup`s, which clones each of their node hierarchies.
Rename the members of `QueryGroup` for clarity.

Remove `QueryGroup::update`, `QueryGroup::update_override`, and `Query::subtables`.

This leaves only a single pointer to each query node within the group,
which should allow us to switch the nodes over to explicit unique
ownership.

The purpose that `update` was serving for `Not` and `subtable` is
replaced by moving reponsibility for creating the node to
`handle_pending_not` and `end_subtable` respectively. The body of their
group is reparented as the `NotNode` / `SubtableNode`'s condition.

`OrNode`'s use of `update_override` requires special handling.
`update_override` was used to have the next node that was added be
appended to `OrNode::m_condition`, and for future nodes to be added as
children of the most recently added condition. We make this sequence
explicit with the `QueryGroup::State` enumeration, which influences the
behavior of `Query::add_node`. When `Query::Or` is called, the current
group's state is set to `OrCondition`. When the next node is added, the
state transitions to `OrConditionChildren`.
Pull `Query`'s per-group state into a `QueryGroup` object.
Rename the `m_cond` member of `OrNode` and `NotNode` to `m_conditions` and `m_condition` respectively.

Move responsibility for holding copies of the data out of `BinaryNode`,
`StringNodeBase` and `StringNode` into new types.

`OwnedBinaryData` and `OwnedStringData` own copies of the data they're
given.

Have `IntegerNodeBase` use an `Optional` to store its value rather than
storing a separate `m_null` flag.

Some cleanup within the query node class heirarchy.

* Empty destructors are removed.
* Copy constructors are explicitly defaulted where possible.
* Copy constructors in derived classes no longer redundantly copy `m_child`.
* Constructors no longer redundantly initialize `m_child` to `nullptr`.
* Initializer list is preferred in constructors where possible.
Remove `ParentNode::child_criteria` now that subclasses use `m_child` consistently.

Have `SubtableNode` use `m_child` for the same purpose as other `ParentNode`s.

Its extra member variable, formerly known as `m_child2`, is renamed to
`m_condition` and represents the conditions on the subtable.
Replace m_conds with m_children.size(), since they should always be the same.

Merge pull request #1161 from realm/mar-unary-link-queries

Allow comparisons involving unary links on both sides of the operator
Fix coding style issues.

Rename `Value::from_link` to `Value::m_from_link_list` to reflect its
new meaning.

Also update comments for accuracy.

Allow comparisons involving unary links on both sides of the operator.

The comparison code currently behaves as though links indicate "many-to-x"
relationships, but that's only the case when dealing with a link
list. Unary links are in fact "one-to-x" relationships, much like normal
column values.

This change results in `Columns<T>::evaluate` producing a `Value` with
`from_link_list` set to `false` when only unary links are involved. This
has the desired effect of sending comparisons and operators down the
"one-to-x" paths rather than the "many-to-x" paths. This prevents
comparisons with unary links on both sides from asserting due to the
"many-to-many" case being undefined.

A side-effect of this change is in how `Columns<T>::evaluate` handles
null unary links. Formerly, an empty `Value` was produced. Now a `Value`
containing a single null is produced.

Merge pull request #1145 from realm/mar-windows-optional-fixes

Fix the build with Visual Studio 2015

Fix the build with Visual Studio 2015.

Visual Studio 2015's support for `constexpr` is less complete than recent
versions of GCC and Clang. The following changes are necessary in order to
make optional.hpp compile:

1. Definition of `none` and `in_place` need to be split from the
   declarations of their respective classes to suppress an error about them
   not being constant.
2. The tests for `constexpr Optional<T&>` are disabled on Windows due to Visual
   Studio believing that many `constexpr` member functions access
   non-constant data.
3. `Empty` is replaced with `char` in `OptionalStorage` as Visual Studio
   complains about one member of the union being uninitialized when that
   member is an empty type.

Merge pull request #1120 from realm/dp-hotfix-0899-release-notes

Release notes for 0.89.9
Expanded the bugfix comment in the release notes

Ensure that the `constexpr` parts of `Optional` compile when used in
constant expressions.

In order to be used in constant expressions, `Optional<T>` must be a
literal type. One constraint on such types is that they are trivially
destructible (i.e., their destructor must do nothing). `Optional<T>` can
satisfy this constraint when `T` is itself trivially destructible. To
accomplish this, we split `Optional`s storage into a separate
`OptionalStorage` type that is specialized based on whether `T` is
trivially destructible. In the trivially-destructible case, the default
destructor is used. In the non-trivially-destructible case, the value's
destructor is explicitly called when the value is engaged.

A second constraint on literal types is that their `constexpr` constructors
must initialize all data members. To achieve this without needing to
initialize the storage used by `T` when constructing a disengaged
`Optional`, we store `T` in an anonymous union along with an empty type.
The empty type is initialized when constructing a disengaged
`OptionalStorage`, with the `T` member being initialized in other cases.
An extra advantage that this technique provides is that the compiler
will track which member of a union in a literal type is active, and will
provide a diagnostic if the program attempts to access any other
member. The end result is that a diagnostic will be generated if a user
attempts to dereference a disengaged `constexpr Optional<T>`.

Fix two issues notices while attempting to use `util::Optional`

1. The const version of `Optional::value` generates a warning with clang
   on OS X due to appearing to return a temporary. Removing the
   default-construction in the `else` case of the ternary operator
   resolves this, and hopefully won't introduce warnings for other compilers.
2. Attempting to initialize an `Optional<int&>` with a const reference
   initializes it to `None` rather than failing to compile as expected.
   This is because `None` provides an implicit conversion from `const
   int&` to `Optional`. Marking `None`s constructor as `explicit`
   prevents this.

Make `Query`s member variables private.

Fix two other query tests that want to force use of query expressions

Fix Query_DeepCopy with `REALM_OLDQUERY_FALLBACK` disabled.

In 5ad0e268, `Query` moved to caching its current descriptor rather than
computing it on demand. This brings with it a requirement that the
descriptor be refetched when the `Query`s table changes. This was not
being done for the two `Expression` subclasses (`UnaryLinkCompare` and
`Compare`), resulting in a null pointer dereference when running the
tests with `REALM_OLDQUERY_FALLBACK` disabled.

This would have been caught by tests, but Query_DeepCopy's attempts to
test the query expression codepaths with `REALM_OLDQUERY_FALLBACK`
enabled were not successful.

Fix for: New util::File::AccessError::get_path() returns the file system path associated with the exception

Remove an outdated comment about Valgrind.

Prior to 2136f4bb, `Value` didn't track how many items were in use so it
was necesary to initialize all items to prevent warnings about the use
of uninitialized memory. `Value` now tracks how many items are in use
and the code the comment is referring to has been removed.

Fix recently-introduced warnings about C-style casts in query_expression.hpp.

Replace them with the appropriate C++-style cast.
Fix aggregates on nullable DateTime columns

Move Value<T>::export2 to NullableVector::operator[].

Replacing the use of EitherIsString within Value<T>::export2 allows us
to use NullableVector::operator[], rather than poking at
NullableVector::m_first directly. The problem that EitherIsString was
addressing is now solved by std::enable_if, which has the benefit of
allowing us to debug assert in the unreachable cases.

Fix numerous warnings about implicit conversions within Value::export2.

Avoid instantiating Value<T>::export2<null> by adding specialized logic
within Value<T>::export_null. There's no need for export_null to attempt
to convert the individual values since the destination will interpret
them all as null.
Fix Value<T>::clone to preserve the values of the from_link and m_values members.

Make NullableVector's copy constructor compile.

Optimize it and NullableVector's copy assignment operator at the same
time. The NullableVector we're copying from has done the work to
determine a suitable null value. There's no reason to duplicate it.
New util::File::AccessError::get_path() returns the file system path associated with the exception

Added copy constructor for BasicRow

There was already a copy constructor defined for BasicRow, but with the
following signature:

    template<class T> template<class U>
    BasicRow<T>(const BasicRow<U>&)

Because the argument has a different template argument (U instead of
T), the default copy constructor was being used. This could cause an
issue as demonstrated in the attached unit test, or when compiling
with the `-fno-elide-constructors` compiler flag.

The issue caused such copy constructed row accessors to not be properly
registered with the table, and wouldn't get updated upon changes.

Always sync distinct TableViews after they are created

The newly created TableView isn't actually populated for its
`m_last_seen_version`, so it needs to be synced even if the version number
would indicate that it's already up-to-date. In practice this always happens
when a Table hasn't been modified since the Group was loaded.

Optimize OR chains in queries

Make OrNode support 2 or more child expressions rather than requiring an OrNode
for each additional condition. Eliminates a stack overflow when too many
conditions were combined with Or() (due to each condition adding a level of
recursion), and improves performance somewhat (457ms -> 278ms for 1k item IN
clause, including binding overhead).

Merge pull request #532 from Tightdb/ks-bugfix-repl-selected-link-list

Bugfix: Replication::m_selected_link_list was not cleared

Add another operator= overload for BasicRow

When T == U, the compiler-generated default `operator=` is used rather than the
`template<class U> BasicRow& operator=(BasicRow<U>)` overload, which meant that
assigning a Row to a ConstRow or vice-versa worked correctly, but assigning a
Row to a Row did not.

None of the current tests actually verified that the user-supplied assignment
operator was being used, so I expanded the
Table_RowAccessorAssignMultipleTables test to also test assigning a Row to
another Row (in addition to assigning a RowExpr to a Row).

Merge branch 'master' of github.com:Tightdb/tightdb

Major upgrade of generic.mk:
 - Support for building dynamic bundles on OS X (now used in Ruby
   binding).
 - Support for loading extra makefiles from config.mk (now used in
   Ruby binding).
 - Installed programs that are linked against project-local installed
   libraries now receive proper -rpath options such that they can be
   executed without setting LD_LIBRARY_PATH on any system and
   regardless of where TightDB is installed.
 - Support for declaring the current directory as being dependent on a
   subdirectory, previously only the opposite was possible.
 - Fixed order problem during install (via introduction of
   'install-only' as new recursive target)
 - Various other fixes.
Removing even more output in interactive mode.

Merge pull request #126 from kneth/fix-print-group

Fix print group

Avoid clobbering the previous database version in GroupWriter::commit() in the non-transactional case.
Eliminate the risk of extending byte size of Group::m_free_positions in GroupWriter::commit() after using its exact size in a calculation.
Eliminate unnecessary free space fragmentation by stopping GroupWriter::reserve_free_space() from adjusting the size of the identified chunk when it is different from the requested size.
GroupWriter::get_fre_space() and Group::Writer::reserve_free_space() now share searching code, and therefore, both skip the first part of the list when searching for a chunk that is larger than 1024 bytes.
Fixed an undetected free-space leak when deleting free-space version tracking in GroupWriter::commit().
More documentation.
Many other improvements.

System put in place to make it easy to build whatever is in "test/experiements/testcase.cpp".
The idea is to make it easy to run a single unit-test from the command line while examining and modifying it.
Here is the general idea: Copy a single unit test of interest into the main function in "test/experiements/testcase.cpp", then run "make testcase" or "make testcase-debug" from the top-level directory of the core-library.

	Makefile

Major Makefiles makeover:
* Last kinks in 'automatic dependency generation' ironed out.
* Full support for parallel building on all targets, i.e. 'make -j4'.
* A simple 'make' or 'make debug' in the 'root' dir will build both a shared and a static library.
* When building with 'debug' enabled, the library names will have a '_d' siffix.
* Object and library files with 'debug' enabled can no longer get mixed up with those where 'debug' is disabled.
* Coverage is now generated from the 'root' dir rather than the 'test' dir.
* Coverage completes with fewer errors (unfound data).
* Coverage is filtered to only include files in 'src' dir.
* Coverage is computed by 'make lcov' rather than 'make gcov'.
* Generated coverage HTML files are placed in 'cover_html' rather than 'test/cov_htmp'.
* Unit tests can be executed by 'make test' in the 'root' dir.
* Unit test execution is monitored by 'valgrind'.
* Benchmarks can be executed by 'make benchmark' in the 'root' dir.
* '.gitignore' was updated as required by the above.
Reference counting in tables references: Memory leaks and access errors fixed. A few memory leaks remain, but are not due to the 'reference counting' changes.
